Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1
9709/53
May/June 2025
1 hour 15 minutes
You must answer on the question paper.
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)
INSTRUCTIONS
• Answer all questions.
• Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.
• Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.
• Write your answer to each question in the space provided.
• Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.
• Do not write on any bar codes.
• If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.
• You should use a calculator where appropriate.
• You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.
• Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.
INFORMATION
• The total mark for this paper is 50.
• The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

**Page 2: Blank Page**
* 0000800000002 *
2
BLANK PAGE
UCLES 2025
9709/53/M/J/25

**Page 3: Question 1**

<question 1>
1 For a set of 40 values of x, it is found that
$$\Sigma(x-k) = 836.0$$
$$\Sigma(x-k)^2 = 25410.8$$
where $k$ is a constant.

<part a>
Given that the mean of these 40 values is 124.0, find the value of $k$.
[2]
</part a>

<part b>
Find the standard deviation of these 40 values of $x$.
[2]
</part b>
</question 1>

**Page 4: Question 2**

<question 2>
2 At a large college, all students who study Science also study exactly one of Art or Drama or Music.
20% of these students study Art, 45% study Drama and 35% study Music.

<part a>
3 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.
Find the probability that at least 1 of these students studies Drama.
[2]
</part a>

<part b>
10 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.
Find the probability that more than 7 study Art or Music.
[3]
</part b>
</question 2>

**Page 5: Question 3**

<question 3>
3 A fair six-sided dice with faces labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is thrown repeatedly until a 3 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable $X$.

<part a>
Find P(X= 8).
[1]
</part a>

<part b>
Find P(X < 9).
[2]
</part b>

<part c>
Find the probability that a 3 is obtained for the second time before the 6th throw.
[3]
</part c>
</question 3>

**Page 6: Question 4 (Part a)**

<question 4>
4 84 people attempt a particular puzzle. The times taken, in minutes, to complete the puzzle are recorded. These times are represented in the cumulative frequency graph below.

<image>
Cumulative frequency graph showing time in minutes (0 to 12) on the x-axis and cumulative frequency (0 to 100) on the y-axis. The curve starts at (0, 0), rises gradually until time 3, then steeply, passing through approximately (5, 50) and leveling off near time 11 towards the maximum cumulative frequency of 84.
</image>

<part a>
Use the graph to estimate how many people took between 4 and 7.5 minutes to complete the puzzle.
[1]
</part a>
</question 4>

**Page 7: Question 4 (Part b)**

<question 4> (Continued)
<part b>
On the grid below, draw a box-and-whisker plot to summarise the information in the cumulative frequency graph.
[4]
<image>An empty grid is provided, suitable for drawing a box-and-whisker plot, with the y-axis labels from the previous page's graph (Cumulative frequency) being absent, suggesting this grid is for the plot aligned with the time axis.</image>
</part b>
</question 4>

**Page 8: Question 5 (Part a)**

<question 5>
5 Bag $A$ contains 6 red marbles, 5 blue marbles and 1 green marble.
Bag $B$ contains 5 red marbles and 3 blue marbles.
A marble is chosen at random from bag $A$ and placed in bag $B$.
A marble is now chosen at random from bag $B$.

<part a>
Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, giving the probability on each branch.
[3]
</part a>
</question 5>

**Page 9: Question 5 (Parts b and c)**

<question 5> (Continued)
<part b>
Find the probability that both marbles chosen are the same colour.
[2]
</part b>

<part c>
Find the probability that the marble chosen from bag $A$ is blue, given that the marble chosen from bag $B$ is blue.
[3]
</part c>
</question 5>

**Page 10: Question 6 (Parts a and b)**

<question 6>
6 A company sells bags of pasta. The masses of large bags of pasta are normally distributed with mean 2.50 kg and standard deviation 0.12 kg.

<part a>
Find the probability that the mass of pasta in a randomly chosen large bag is less than 2.65 kg.
[2]
</part a>

A restaurant manager buys 160 of these large bags of pasta.

<part b>
Find the number of bags for which you would expect the mass of pasta to be more than 1.65 standard deviations above the mean.
[3]
</part b>
</question 6>

**Page 11: Question 6 (Part c)**

<question 6> (Continued)
The masses of small bags of pasta sold by the company are normally distributed with mean $\mu$ kg and standard deviation $\sigma$ kg. Tests show that 77% of these bags have masses greater than 1.26 kg, and 44% have masses less than 1.35 kg.

<part c>
Find, in either order, the value of $\mu$ and the value of $\sigma$.
[5]
</part c>
</question 6>

**Page 12: Question 7 (Parts a and b)**

<question 7>
7 A set of friends consists of 7 men and 4 women. Three of the men are brothers: Ali, Ben and Charlie.

<part a>
Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men in a line in which Ali and Ben do not stand next to each other.
[3]
</part a>

<part b>
Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men and 4 women in a line in which all the men stand together and all the women stand together.
[3]
</part b>
</question 7>

**Page 13: Question 7 (Parts c and d)**

<question 7> (Continued)
<part c>
In how many ways can the 7 men and 4 women be divided into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 if there are no restrictions?
[2]
</part c>

<part d>
The 7 men and 4 women are divided at random into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2.
Find the probability that Ali, Ben and Charlie are all in the same group.
[4]
</part d>
</question 7>
